captions.text: Oakley #disruptors
5 x Disruptive Athletes
Disruptor No.5: Mark Cavendish
After excelling as a track cyclist, Cavendish turned his focus to road racing.
Adopting a unique position on the bike, he quickly emerged as a dynamic sprinter.
I have a style on a bike like no one else. I really use a bike,
I really get over the front end of a bike and really twist the bike into my body
rather than try and put power down through the bike.
I remember when I was young, when I was sprinting, it was kind of like a desperation thing,
like the further forward you are the quicker you're going to get to the finish line, you know?
Cavendish works closely with bike manufacturers to ensure his equipment meets the demands of his riding style.
The stresses I put on a bike is in completely different places to what other people do.
I'm lucky I have some great partners, but I really push them for optimum performance.
you know?
I can be difficult to work with to get things right but I always have a reasoning behind what I want.
I use a size small frame, a 49cm frame, which is a kids bike really you know,
it's the smallest frame you can possibly get with 28 inch wheels, which makes it incredibly stiff and responsive.
I get through a bike every couple of months just because I twist the bike so much that it softens the carbon.
Normal people go a whole year without a bike even changing the shape
but I really put so much stress through the frames that we have to layer it with extra carbon.
Despite sprinting to speeds of up to 48mph, Cavendish insists on calculation over adrenaline.
Perception of sprinters is that it's this adrenaline-fuelled, boxing match at the end of a bike race,
there's elbows going and everyone's just crazy-eyed to get to the finish.
How I see it is I don't see other riders, I see spaces between riders.
I'm really calm and calculated with what I do.
I really absorb my surroundings, everything that's going on, and it enables me to
one, make decisions easier and two, keeps my heart rate down.
If my heart rate's down I'm going to have more energy at the end.
Before I even race I do a lot of puzzles, a lot of logic puzzles and I play chess as well.
It's kinda like how sports psychologists tell you to view things,
and what to do, and eliminate emotion and look at the task in hand.
I've always done that anyway, I have this way of thinking like that.
I see lines, I see things that other people don't really take in, I absorb everything and it works in a bike race.
In 2012 Cavendish became the first person in history to win the final stage of the Tour de France four years in a row.
The Champs-Élysées is known as the holy grail for sprinters.
Most great sprinters have won there you know, it's the stage of the Tour de France,
the last stage of the Tour de France, , if you reach Paris you've finished the Tour de France,
you've finished arguably the hardest sporting event on the planet.
It's always ram packed the whole circuit. There's a tunnel you do at the bottom of the circuit,
and as you come out the circuit the crowd's there but it's silence in the tunnel
and you come out and then all of a sudden: boom, this roar.
The crowd, it's incredible, it gives you goosebumps, and for the rest of the race
then there's just this tunnel of noise, it really does stand the hairs up on your skin.
I think crossing the finish line, seeing the Arc de Triomphe in front of you, it's...
there's not a feeling in cycling that compares to that.
It's a pretty special day for me to even ride on the Champs-Élysées, let alone win there.
Cavendish's disruptive style has made him one of the most competitive sprinters in road race cycling.
